Open Source Toolchain for Drone Mapping

The steps below provide a case study example on how to use low cost open hardware and open software for collecting aerial photographs and derive a map. Specifically we list and explain:

  • Assembling hardware
  • Installing software
  • Prepare an autopilot survey mission
  • Carry out the mission
  • Process data

Hardware setting for flying mission

  • UAVs
  • Sensors for environmental monitoring, conservation, agriculture, site planning, archeology, building site.
  • Connection UAV to sensor.
  • Batteries

Software installation

  • CHDK, STICK hands on camera software and scripting requirements for automatic data capture.
  • Mission planner (ground station software) on the OSGeo-live virtual machine. - hands on Mission Planner.
  • Parametrization setting to trigger the camera with the pixhawk autopilot.
  • Survey mission definition - hands on 3DR Tower an alternative ground station software.

Data acquisition

  • Setting ground georeference points.
  • Setting reflectance reference colour targets for later image parametrisation.
  • Double check hardware functioning.
  • UAV flight mission on the field.

UAV Data processing

  • Downloading images
  • Downloading log files from pixhawk - hands on log files
  • Geotagging images with log files - hands on geotaggin
  • Data processing toolchain with OpendroneMap (Lecture - Hands on).
  • Online processing Web Processing Service for OpenDroneMap
  • FlyElephant cloud platform for OpenDroneMap processing
  • Plot results in QGIS and MeshLab
  • Store data within open access data repository OpenAerialMap
